title: Monday, 31st May, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE

Off we go then. Good morning, hello, welcome.

BE

Paul's elsewhere. Can't remember specifically why. Sure it was a good reason though.

BE

Which means I get to choose the portrait of the day.

11:04 am
BE

Which today is ........

BE

BE

That's the Lamb's Temperance Hotel in Reform Street, Dundee.

11:05 am
BE

As owned firstly by Thomas Lamb, then latterly by his son Alexander

BE

An odd chap who collected stuff and took to chronicling local history with the enthusiasm of a man who's not allowed to drink.

BE

Then, around 1900, the building went to some guys with beards who were making a lot of money selling railway bonds to jute barons

11:06 am
BE

They used it as an office until 2008, when this lady took over.

BE

BE

She moved them up the road to West Marketgait, into a sinister glass box just round the corner from Groucho's

11:07 am
BE

........ But spent rather more time in Davos than Dundee, so last year was paid to go away

BE

And now -- yes, there is a point to all this! -- here's what happens .....

BE

Alliance Trust confirms approach by Jacob Rothschild

11:08 am
BE

Informal proposal from RIT Capital Partners for a £5bn combination

BE

https://next.ft.co...-8b18-91555f2f4fde

Alliance Trust PLC (ATST:LSE): Last: 526.50, up 18 (+3.54%), High: 528.00, Low: 518.00, Volume: 718.39k
11:09 am
RIT Capital Partners (RCP:LSE): Last: 1,594, down 24.7 (-1.53%), High: 1,600, Low: 1,590, Volume: 82.20k
BE

......... So, the story seems to have done a favour to Alliance and not to RIT.

BE

Because the only way this makes sense, really, is if RIT uses its premium-to-NAV stock to buy Alliance's discount-to-NAV stock.

11:11 am
BE

The latter's discount is down to, what, 6 or 7% this morning?

BE

I note also, incidentally, that Alliance continued to buy back its own shares after receiving the "informal" offer ........ Sure that's fine legally, but it makes me a little uncomfortable.

BE

Anyway, here's Stifel to say, "this looks less than perfect."

11:12 am
BE

Stifel comment: This is a surprise move by RIT Capital (RCP.LN, 1,619p,
Neutral), which appears to be taking advantage of its shares trading on a
premium, to make an approach for Alliance which is trading on a low
double-digit discount. However, the two trusts are quite different, with Alliance
primarily having an equity portfolio, whereas RIT has a multi-asset portfolio.
The RIT portfolio includes significant exposure to unquoted investments and at
times other strategies including long/short equity funds. If the board of Alliance
rejects the RIT approach because it is seen as an unsuitable partner, it is
possible that some trusts that primarily invest in equities could come along as
other potential partners and ‘white knights’. It could be an interesting summer
for the investment companies sector. We note the announcements from both
parties this morning and it appears that the Alliance board wants to consider
all options as part of its strategic review and this is likely to take some time.
Key points from Alliance’s RNS response: ...significant changes to Alliance
Trust have been implemented in order to enhance shareholder value and to
better position the Company to deliver consistent outperformance in a
cost-effective manner. As part of that process, changes have been made to
the composition of the Company’s Board of Directors to make it fully
independent and comprised solely of non-executive directors, including the
appointment of Lord Smith of Kelvin as Chairman in February 2016.
The Company wishes to explore all options available to it for the long-term
future benefit of shareholders and expects that the strategic review outcome
may not be determined for some months.

BE

The Board notes recent press speculation relating to an unsolicited approach
received and confirms that RIT Capital Partners plc has approached Alliance
Trust with an informal proposal for a merger of the two companies. No detailed
terms have been provided by RIT with regard to the proposal or in respect of
the Company’s two principal operating subsidiaries. The Board of Alliance
Trust will incorporate any formal merger proposal received from RIT into its
strategic review, alongside the other options.
There is no certainty that any transaction will result from the review.
Shareholders are strongly advised to take no action and to await the outcome
of the strategic review.
As a consequence of this announcement, the Company is now considered to
be in an “Offer Period” as defined in the City Code on Takeovers and Mergers.
The Company is required to suspend share buy backs.
RIT must, by 5.00 pm on 27 June 2016, being the 28th day following the date
of this announcement, either announce a firm intention to make an offer for the
Company or announce that it does not intend to make an offer for the
Company under Rule 2.8 of the Code, unless the Takeover Panel agrees
otherwise in accordance with Rule 2.6(c) of the Code.

BE

(@Mo: too far off topic. The internet's a big place.)

11:13 am
BE

So .........

BE

I guess we can go back to the old argument about what you get when you buy a fund manager.

BE

Redemptions run at 20% a year.

11:14 am
BE

Which makes sense, given the average life of a fund mandate is only 3 to 5 years,

BE

You're acquiring contracts.

BE

As in, the client list and the employment contracts of those in the building.

11:16 am
BE

Both of whom are likely to consider their options under new management.

BE

And the whole reason the asset manager is purchasable is that the investments have been performing badly, so one would expect that redemption rate to be above average anyway.

BE

So yeah, perhaps a white knight will appear as speculated by Stifel.

11:18 am
BE

Or perhaps the potential for a bid will close the NAV gap and thereby kill the idea of a takeover

BE

Meaning Alliance can remain in its sinister glass box round the corner from Groucho's.

BE

We'll see, I guess. But my money would be on option 2.

11:19 am
undefined
BE

(@roddy1234: is that right? If so, I stand corrected.)

BE

So, FTSE. Down a bit.

11:20 am
BE

Comments slow due to half term.

BE

(And also the lack of news, but let's not dwell on that.)

BE

Oh, and it's the FTSE rejig tonight.

11:22 am
BE

Or rather, tomorrow based on today's closing prices.

BE

We'll nearly definitely be saying farewell to Inmarsat

BE

(@Roddy: well, exactly.)

11:23 am
Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 738.47, down 10.03 (-1.34%), High: 751.00, Low: 738.47, Volume: 312.50k
BE

And hello, again, to Hikma.

Hikma Pharmaceuticals PLC (HIK:LSE): Last: 2,273, up 48 (+2.16%), High: 2,293, Low: 2,238, Volume: 281.71k
11:24 am
BE

As for the FTSE 250 ..........

BE

BE

· Ascential

· CMC Markets

· Countryside Properties

· CYBG

· Hill & Smith Hldgs

· Metro Bank

· Smurfit Kappa Group

11:25 am
BE

And outgoing are .............

BE

· Highbridge Multi-Strategy Fund

· Interserve

· Jimmy Choo

· Lookers

· Melrose Industries

· Northgate

· Ophir Energy

BE

Ascential?

11:26 am
BE

Oh, Top Right Group. Of course.

BE

https://next.ft.co...-8d70-42b68cfae6e4

BE

............ Just looking for the small cap side ..........

11:30 am
BE

.......... and not finding. Sorry. SocGen and JPM usually do previews but neither seems to have bothered this time around.

BE

........ Well, that was a dead end. Apologies.

undefined
11:32 am
BE

Speaking of Ophir, though ...........

Ophir Energy PLC (OPHR:LSE): Last: 71.05, up 1.05 (+1.50%), High: 72.05, Low: 70.55, Volume: 747.57k
BE

Deutsche pushing.

11:32 am
BE

Having just rejigged its E&P team.

BE

E in for free, is the gist.

BE

Also sellers of Genel, which we'll get to in a moment.

11:33 am
BE

Sentiment on the E&Ps has clearly clawed its way back from the low-point of the cycle in late January. We estimate that NAVs discount an average oil price of $61.5/bbl, which is broadly in line with the forward curve, and that $45/bbl oil is required over 2016-18 for the group to achieve cash flow neutrality. We also forecast that all E&Ps can organically de-leverage to below 2.0x ND/EBITBAX, based on a return to $70/bbl in 2018. However, Brent breaking out above $50/bbl has buoyed the sector and our inclination is now to adopt a more cautious short-term stance on oil price, sector and higher beta names.

BE

The international E&P sector has proved remarkably resilient to the down-cycle in commodity prices. Cutting exploration budgets first, then development capex, before finally rounding on operating costs, should allow the sector to advance cash flow neutrality by 6M into 17H1 at the forward curve. We think that project IRRs may ultimately end up benefitting more from cost deflation than they did from higher prices. Nonetheless, the OFS contractors will need to sharpen their pencils further and accept yet thinner margins to get the sector recommitting capex through a new cycle of project sanctions.

BE

The boom has gone, but the debt still looms large – aggregate net debt is forecast to peak at c.$12bn in 2H16. Our E&P producers are currently focused on redressing the imbalance between equity and credit (48%:52%) by directing cash flows towards balance sheet remediation rather than reinvestment. However, the sector represents more than just a geared oil price play and paying down debt is hardly an attractive investment case for equity investors. With reduced visibility on long term growth prospects, we think the sector needs to articulate exactly where NAV upside will come from in the future.

11:35 am
BE

Ophir Energy (Buy, 90p TP) – Our stand-out value opportunity. We think the current share price is supported by Core NAV and offers a free option on the Equatorial Guinea FLNG project achieving project sanction in the next 12M.
Africa Oil (Buy, SEK16.5 TP) – We think further divestment in Kenya is likely over the next 12M, by Tullow and/or Africa Oil, which should provide valuation support above the existing $1/bbl level (2C/EV) implied in the share price.
Genel Energy (SELL, 106p TP) – The KRG’s financial affairs continue to look strained and there is much work to do on rebuilding confidence in the asset base following the Taq Taq reserves downgrade earlier this year.

BE

It's Total that's meant to be buying the Africa-Tullow Kenya acreage, isn't it?

Tullow Oil PLC (TLW:LSE): Last: 233.00, down 5.2 (-2.18%), High: 242.40, Low: 231.00, Volume: 1.78m
11:36 am
BE

That story's been around for some time. Not sure if it's entirely speculation or something more substantive.

BE

Otherwise on oil, we're waiting for word from an irrelevant Opec meeting

BE

And Kurdistan's apparently clarified last week's measly payments

11:39 am
BE

Though they done it via Twitter and I can't find the relevant tweet.

BE

This is Markets Live, the FT's daily thing with the typing.

BE

Upshot is that payments were two-thirds one-third and the final installment will be made today.

11:40 am
BE

Like buying a sofa from DFS.

BE

Oh, and while we're here ..............

BE

(Bloomberg) -- Gulf Keystone is in talks with potential new money providers to help restructure its debt, according to people familiar with the discussions, who asked not to be identified because the matter is private.
Co. is in negotiations with investors who may inject new money in exchange for stake in restructured business
Bondholders will swap some of their holdings for majority of equity
Moratorium on debt payments may be extended beyond today to allow enough time for negotiations
Gulf Keystone spokesman Mark Antelme declined to comment on the restructuring or the talks with new investors

11:41 am
Gulf Keystone Petroleum Ltd (GKP:LSE): Last: 4.92, up 0.135 (+2.82%), High: 5.00, Low: 4.60, Volume: 1.95m
BE

Pre-emption rights? Pah. Way to far gone for that kind of thinking.

undefined
11:42 am
BE

Okay, seems we have comment problems.

BE

Getting emails to the effect that the comment box disappeared.

BE

Apologies. It's not something I have the power to fix on the fly.

11:44 am
BE

Thanks to the chaps at N+1 Singer for forwarding over their FTSE preview though.

BE

Which means we have the ins and outs for the smallcaps.

BE

Out: Centaur Media, Aberdeen New Thai, Blackrock ComIncIt, LMS Capital, Lakehouse and ....

11:46 am
BE

.... Johnston Press.

BE

Deary me. The owner of the Scotsman dropping into the FTSE Fledgling.

BE

Into the smalls we have ...............

11:46 am
BE

VinaCapital VTM

BE

On The Beach

BE

Forterra

11:47 am
BE

Target Healthcare Reit

BE

Tarsus

BE

Hentersin International Inc TST

11:47 am
BE

Phoenix Spree DTL

BE

Funding Circle SME

BE

Schroder Eur Reit Trust

11:48 am
BE

Edison Property Investment Co

BE

And Lindsell Train.

BE

That's what, three actual companies and ten investment trusts....

11:49 am
BE

.......... Anyway, all indicative. Results depend on tonight's placings.

BE

And ta, N+1.

undefined
11:50 am
BE

This is no fun without comments.

BE

(Because it's usually great. fun ........)

BE

What else should we note? There's the PostNL story I guess.

11:51 am
BE

BPost was in takeover talks to buy PostNL, but now it's not.

BE

After suspending the shares of both on Friday and saying "we'll tell you what's going on before Monday"

BE

Which is a reasonable way to do things, I guess. Even if the result -- a pens down post leak -- is the same.

11:53 am
BE

Credit Suisse kicks around the theme of mail consolidation.

BE

bpost/PostNL discussions follow global logistics consolidation trend –
investor interest likely to intensify: Following RMG being linked with
PostNL in December 2015, bpost and PostNL (each Not Rated) have
confirmed merger discussions which have proved unfruitful (to date). M&A is
becoming a bigger theme in the European postal space, following an uptick in
global logistics combination activity in express (from FedEx/TNT and Japan
Post/Toll), in freight forwarding (DSV/UTi, XPO/Norbert Dentressangle) and in
container shipping (CMA CGM/NOL, China COSCO/CSCL, HapagLloyd/CSAV and potentially UASC). We expect increasing investor focus on
the theme and address its relevance to Royal Mail (Neutral, TP 490p) and
Deutsche Post DHL (Underperform, TP €23.40).

BE

Three key points on sector M&A prospects: (i) the primary rationale for a
bpost/PostNL combination would likely be to boost parcel growth
prospects via a stronger combined platform: This development suggests
second tier parcel operators would potentially feel better positioned together
dealing with new threats such as Amazon Logistics, and also for bpost/PostNL
in dealing with DHL Parcel's expansion outside Germany. Scale will also be
increasingly important in the context of relevant to global e-commerce
customers and Express industry concentration (FDX/TNT) as postal operators
seek to manage the gap to global express powerhouses DHL, UPS and
FedEx, (ii) achieving meaningful synergies likely difficult in heavily
unionised labour environments: With c50% of sector cost bases comprised
of heavily unionised labour, we see potential M&A synergies as somewhat
limited. This, in combination with declining traditional mail volumes, is likely to
impact appetite for large scale M&A somewhat, and (iii) Royal Mail seems a
more likely driver of consolidation than DP DHL but we do not see an
obvious acquisition candidate: We do not expect DHL to make meaningful
acquisitions given its prioritisation of organic growth. However, RMG is
focused on adding new revenue streams (even from maintaining third party
vehicles) so may have more appetite to consolidate the fragmented UK parcel
market where overcapacity runs at 20% (potentially difficult from a regulatory
perspective given its 50% share and Ofcom's focus on healthy competition) or
even to boost GLS prospects in the European B2C express market once a UK
labour deal is achieved. With 2016A net debt 0.2x adjusted EBITDA, RMG's
financial position is strong. This said, we have previously highlighted our
doubts about PostNL's abilities to add value to RMG (RMG: PostNL deal
seems unlikely, 4 January 2016) while we do not see obviously acquirable
candidates among RMG's key parcel competitors (DPD owned by La Poste,
Hermes owned by otto group, Yodel 5%-owned by Amazon and TNT Express
now part of FedEx).

11:54 am
BE

All of which looks fair enough.

BE

Consolidation makes sense hypothetically but none of the companies can buy each other.

Royal Mail PLC (RMG:LSE): Last: 539.50, up 7 (+1.31%), High: 539.50, Low: 529.00, Volume: 854.64k
11:55 am
BE

So, Royal Mail remains a play on Ofcom's vagaries.

undefined
BE

Oh, also wanted to mention this CVC Capital deal.

11:56 am
BE

Buying Sisal of Italy yesterday for E1bn

BE

CVC owns 80% of Sky Bet and recently bought a majority of Tipico, the leading German bookie.

BE

It looks awfully like CVC is building a pan-European bookmaker

11:57 am
BE

Which, firstly, rather reduces the chance that it'll ever come in for Ladbrokes

Ladbrokes PLC (LAD:LSE): Last: 134.80, down 1.5 (-1.10%), High: 136.50, Low: 134.30, Volume: 791.61k
BE

Or William Hill, given the regulatory constraints.

11:58 am
William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 314.20, up 1.7 (+0.54%), High: 314.60, Low: 310.90, Volume: 365.77k
BE

Though it does make a more formidable competitor in several important markets, given CVC will likely drive the business pretty hard ahead of an exit.

undefined
12:00 pm
BE

Okay, nearly done.

BE

Want a massive slab of Deutsche Bank strategy to read over lunch?

BE

Probably not, but you've no way of telling me that given comments are broken.

12:00 pm
BE

So you're getting it anyway.

BE

Sebastian Raedler is the analyst here. He has five questions.

BE

1) Can the oil price hold up even as the dollar rises?
2) Can the CNY depreciate without hurting asset prices?
3) Will European equities rally as Brexit fears are being priced out?
4) Is there scope for earnings upgrades?
5) Will value stocks finally start outperforming?

12:02 pm
BE

(@BBOC: they do. It's still printed and mailed out on heavy duty paper, like Granta for spods.)

BE

So, let's go through these.

BE

1)Can the oil price hold up even as the dollar rises?
The oil price has risen above $50/bbl this week, despite a number of negative catalysts: a) the broad dollar TWI is up
3% since the start of May on increased market expectations for a Fed rate hike - consistent with oil below $40/bbl,
according to historical correlations; b) iron ore has already dropped by 30% from its late April peak as the China
rebound has faded (historically the correlation with the oil price has been very strong at around 60%); and c) the oil
price has rallied far ahead of what sluggish global economic momentum would have suggested. Oil remains crucial,
given that it has been the key driver of US high-yield credit spreads in this cycle, with the risk premium for European
equities in turn moving in line with credit spreads.
n The benign scenario: the positive price impact of the tightening in the oil market continues to outweigh the
negative catalysts – pushing the oil price higher or keeping it at least stable. This allows US high-yield credit
spreads to remain at current tight levels, thus preventing a renewed outbreak of credit stress. n The risk scenario: the oil price drops again as the USD rises further and the slowdown in China becomes more pronounced, putting renewed upward pressure on credit spreads and hurting equity performance.

n Our view: our commodity analysts expect Brent crude to finish the year close to current levels, at $50/bbl. We are worried about downside risks relative to this scenario, given that the USD, a potentially negative catalyst, has been a more reliable determinant of the oil price over the past ten years (R2 of 80%) than the balance in the oil market, the potentially positive catalyst (R2 of 40%). Any weakness in the oil price would likely have a negative impact on credit and equity markets.

12:03 pm
BE

Formatting might be a bit duff at times. Sorry about that.

BE

2)Can the CNY depreciate without hurting equities?
The Chinese currency has depreciated by 1.6% against the dollar since mid-April, against the backdrop of a broad
dollar rebound. CNY weakness is a function of Fed tightening expectations, and is therefore likely to intensify as Fed
hikes become more likely. Chinese authorities face difficulty in supporting their currency through higher rates given
high private sector debt and weakening growth momentum. DB forecasts a weakening of over 6% in CNY by the end
of the year (to USD/CNY 7.0). This points to downside to European equities, which have tracked USD/CNY closely
since the middle of last year.
n The benign scenario: the fact that the PBoC’s CNY basket is already below the target level of 100 and that
authorities have managed to stop capital outflows suggests both, that depreciation risk is lower than it was in
mid-2015 and early-2016 (when the CNY basket was clearly above 100) and that a depreciation against the
dollar could be less problematic for global risk assets this time round (if it does not translate into renewed
capital outflows). Furthermore, the upcoming G20 Summit in September hosted by China means they are
unlikely to rock the boat in the near-term.
n The risk scenario: the PBoC’s basket is merely a reference rate rather than a hard peg, as our China economist
argues, and CNY weakness driven by Fed tightening triggers more capital flight since leakage through trade
channels in particular have not been fixed. This sparks concerns of a) renewed capital outflows and FX reserve
draw-downs, leading to tighter global financial conditions; b) weaker commodity prices, as a lower CNY
depresses Chinese commodity imports; c) the renewed risk of a sharp one-off devaluation in China to stem
reserve losses.
n Our view: We are not convinced by the argument that Chinese FX vulnerability has been reduced significantly.
6% downside to our FX strategists USD/CNY target of 7.0 by year-end would weigh significantly on the
European equity market.

BE

3)Will European equities rally as Brexit concerns are priced out?
Bookmakers’ odds of a pro-EU UK referendum result have risen to 80%, even as polls have remained close. The 5-
year UK sovereign CDS spread relative to that for Germany – a neat proxy for Brexit concerns – has fallen to 13bps,
half the mid-April peak levels, suggesting the market is becoming increasingly confident that Jun 23 will be a vote for
the status quo. European equities have rallied by 4% over the past week, as peripheral sovereign spreads have
tightened on the back of reduced Brexit concerns and Greece’s deal with its creditors.
n The benign scenario: increased confidence in a pro-EU vote in the UK referendum and the start of the ECB’s
TLTRO2 program in June leads to a further tightening in peripheral bond spreads, in line with projections by
our European fixed income strategists, who expect spreads to tighten by a further 20bps. This would point to
a further 6% upside for European equities. Similarly, our P/E model suggests 4% re-rating potential if a positive
referendum outcome allows European macro uncertainty to fall back to its 10-year average
n The risk scenario: a number of political risk events in Europe over the coming months – Spain’s general
election on June 26th and Italy’s constitutional referendum in October – ensure that macro uncertainty and
peripheral spreads remain elevated.
n Our view: a further reduction in the European risk premium – as reflected in peripheral bond spreads – is a
genuine upside risk in the near-term. However, it is by no means a foregone conclusion, given the potential
negative catalysts highlighted above. Furthermore, we think there is a risk that any reduction in the Europespecific risk premium would be outweighed by the negative impact of a possible deterioration in the global
risk factors affecting the European equity market (US high-yield credit, the fading of China’s growth rebound
and a Fed-inspired tightening in global financial conditions).

12:04 pm
BE

PDF formatting with line breaks is the bane of my ....... well, it's a mild irritation.

BE

4)Is there scope for earnings upgrades?
Our US strategists expect earnings growth to turn in Q2 on the back of a weaker dollar, stronger commodity prices
and a stronger service sector. US and global earnings revisions are about to move into positive territory, while
European consensus earnings have benefitted from upward revisions to resource earnings.
n The benign scenario: 2016 European consensus EPS growth, currently at 0.1%, could move up by 2
percentage points, assuming that commodity prices remain at current levels. If the euro falls by 2% (roughly in
line with our FX strategists’ expectations), this could boost EPS growth by another 2 percentage points. Lastly,
if global GDP growth rebounds to 3.0% in market FX terms (up from 2.7% in Q4 – and significantly above our
economists’ forecast of 2.5%), this could push 2016 European EPS growth to around 8%.
n The risk scenario: manufacturing PMIs point to further downside for global GDP growth. If consensus global
GDP growth moves from 2.8% towards our economists’ forecasts of 2.5% or below, EPS growth in Europe
could turn clearly negative. Furthermore, if commodity prices decline again on the back of renewed dollar
strength and fading Chinese credit stimulus, as our commodity analysts suggest, this would further hurt
European EPS growth.
n Our view: We forecast European EPS growth of minus 2% on the basis of our scenario analysis. In our central
scenario (50% probability), EPS growth is slightly positive at 1%, as the benefit of a slightly weaker euro (down
2% until the end of 2016) and marginally higher commodity prices is offset by a weakening in global growth
(FX-weighted growth rate of 2.5% in 2016). However, in our stress scenario (35%), in which China slows
sharply and credit spreads widen again, EPS growth turns clearly negative. We only see a 15% probability of
our upside scenario, in which European EPS growth rebounds to around 8% in line with the scenario
discussed above. We note that the key driver of US profit growth (real unit labour cost growth) still points to
downside risk for profits (which would negatively affect investment growth and GDP growth). We would need
to see higher inflation and stable wage growth for real ULC growth to fall (yet, a tightening labor market
means there is a risk that real ULC growth remains high, further hurting profit growth).

BE

Last bit.

12:04 pm
BE

5)Will value stocks finally start outperforming?
European value stocks have underperformed growth stocks by 30% since 2006. Relative valuations are depressed –
and our positioning indicators suggest that investors are clearly long growth versus value. Over the past four months,
European value stocks have outperformed growth stocks by 4%, leading some to hope that they could stage a
rebound similar to that during the early 2000s, when they outperformed by 90% over six years.
n The benign scenario: Value stocks could continue to outperform growth stocks if a) bond yields rise (with
bond-like consumer staples needing lower bond yields to perform – and banks benefitting from higher bond
yields), b) the oil price rises (as this supports the energy sector directly – and helps to keep credit spreads
tight, which helps banks), and c) the dollar weakens (helping to support the oil price).
n The risk scenario: The current benign environment for value stocks – rising bond yields and a stronger oil price
– proves fleeting, removing the support factors required for a sustained bout of value outperformance.
n Our view: We fear that any Fed-inspired rebound in bond yields, which has supported banks over the past
weeks, could prove self-defeating if a Fed rate hike leads to a renewed rise in financial stress (which should
lead to lower bond yields on safe haven flows). We are also not convinced that the oil price can keep rising in
an environment of dollar strength and a fading Chinese growth rebound (see above). Hence, we remain
cautious on the outlook for European value versus growth stocks

undefined
BE

So, we're done.

12:06 pm
BE

I say "we" ........... The left's down 50% and the right's been decimated.

BE

Hopefully the tech will work tomorrow.

BE

Otherwise, I could just come round your offices individually and shout opinions through the air vents. I'd probably be a more efficient use of all our time.

12:07 pm
BE

Anyway, cheers for bearing with. See you Wednesday.

BE

https://twitter.com/kurdistanregion?lang=en-gb
